ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much in this class and from Professor Chalioti. I was able to learn about the impacts of artificial intelligence and innovation of various different industries and how these impact the consumer market. She brought real-life examples to class that allowed me to connect the dots between the lectures and the present economy and current companies in the market. It was all very interesting and engaging.
innovation, patents and copyright requirements, vertical integration, durable goods, royalties, price discrimination, use of AI in some industries
I learned about the economics of innovation and the ways AI is transforming several industries.
Incentives for innovation, patent regulations, durable goods, competition, industry analysis etc.
Good

I learned about the economic of artificial intelligence, innovation, prizes and patents. I also learned quite a bit about different industries, how to perform an industry analysis, and some of the details of the U.S. patent system. This course is great because Professor Chalioti takes care to teach pre-professional skills as well as advanced microeconomic theory.

Continuation of knowledge taught in intermediate microeconomics; topics include solving for price/quantity/profit while accounting for price discrimination, mergers, supplier power, searching costs, patents, and other factors.

- Different industry uses of AI
- Profit-maximization
- Economics impacts of AI/tech
- Incentives/awards
- Patents, copyrights, etc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: Professor was very engaging and the material was very interesting. I really liked how we went over a topic in broader terms at the beginning and then dug into the math and the details once we had established a basic understanding. 

Weakness: We only met once a week. I wish we could have met more! I loved coming to class. If you had to miss a week, you fell behind pretty easily.

Strength: Prof Chalioti is extremely organized and kind; the content is very interesting; workload is manageable 
Weakness: could be difficult if you aren't good at intermediate micro because the course only meets once a week and the content moves fast.
No weakness, just strengths. Eva is such a great professor and wants you to succeed.

Strengths: very well-structured lectures with interesting examples. Psets and exams are very manageble.
Weakness: basically none, except that I would like to see more AI-related materials.
Good

Professor Chalioti is an incredible professor and her lectures are so well organized. She is so passionate about the topics she teaches and is awesome at explaining difficult topics. There is also a lot of help with the problem sets, which is great. The content can be quite challenging at times, but she takes care to explain topics in detail and makes really fair exams. The assignments are also really fun!

Strengths: a good introduction to pricing under more complicated circumstances that what is taught in intermediate microeconomics. The class is straightforward and has a fairly low weekly time requirement. 

Weaknesses: does not have a substantial focus on AI innovation beyond the weekly student presentations.

Strengths: Really interesting and engaging topics. Problem sets facilitated learning, and class was well-taught/organized. Industry analysis project was great, and final exam was very fair.
Weaknesses: None. (Though would've been nice to get more feedback on our industry analyses.)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. I have already recommended the class to all of my friends. I absolutely loved the subjects that we learned about and how the class was taught. I think it will be very beneficial to me in the future and with my future career plans.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in innovation and AI (in any industry). It's two hour, once a week seminar in which we spend about 2/3 of the class listening to Prof Chalioti lecturing, and the rest is student presentation. Workload is definitely manageable and the content is super interesting. Prof Chalioti designed the course extremely well, so we cover different topic almost every week (which means things move fast). If you can get a spot in this course, please take it!!
I would recommend every student to take this course. It was my favorite senior economics seminar.
Yes.
Good

Yes! This is a great class if you want to get both pre-professional exposure about things like patents, prizes, and industry analyses, but it also gives you very good mathematical backing of advanced microeconomic theory. It can be quite challenging at times, but if you do the psets and take time to understand the concepts for each week, it should be alright. It's a cool class and it feels more hands-on than any other class I've taken at Yale. Professor Chalioti also makes sure to include a lot of real-life examples and we got great insights into innovation and AI in many different sectors.
Yes if youre looking for a easy 400 level course and want to learn some new topics at a comfortable pace.
Yes! Awesome class.
